awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MTM 1: Decoding the genomic rules of denitrification in bacterial communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbes perform chemistry in the soils, oceans, and even our bodies. They accomplish this collectively in communities composed of many distinct members, each with their genetically-encoded capabilities, all participating in an intricate metabolic trade network. The health and robustness of organisms and ecosystems alike depend on the metabolism of microbes. A deep understanding of the principles that predict the collective metabolism of microbial communities would grant us the ability to control and engineer these communities for the betterment of human health, and the health of our environment. DNA sequencing is one of our most powerful tools for characterizing microbes. Unfortunately, it remains challenging to relate the DNA sequences to the metabolic capabilities of a microbial community. This problem is challenging given the complexity of cellular physiology, and the many complex interactions between different species. Using natural bacterial isolates that perform denitrification, a process that makes up an important part of the nitrogen cycle, mathematical modeling, and machine learning, the researchers will show that it is possible to predict community metabolism from genomic sequences. The work is groundbreaking because it means that by sequencing the DNA of complex communities one can now "readout" their metabolic function. The insight will enable the design of microbial communities with predefined metabolic function. Other broader impacts of this research include training of undergraduate researchers in biochemical, statistical, and computational research and outreach to parents and children regarding microbiomes and denitrification.  

The collective metabolic function of microbial communities emerges through a hierarchy of genomically-encoded processes, from sub-cellular information processing and gene expression to interactions mediated by extracellular metabolites, abiotic factors, and collective phenomena. Understanding how this collective metabolic function is encoded in the genomic structure of the consortium is a core challenge for microbial ecology. This research proposed leverages denitrification, a cascade of reactions that reduce oxidized nitrogen compounds via anaerobic respiration, as a model metabolic function to build a bridge between genomic structure and metabolic function in microbial communities. By employing metabolite measurements on a library of sequenced denitrifying bacterial isolates, the researchers will determine the predictive quantitative relationship between the denitrification genes that each strain possesses and metabolic dynamics. Community assembly experiments will then be used to predict community metabolic dynamics from the dynamics of individual populations. In cases where community dynamics are not predictable from the dynamics of individual populations alone, the researchers will investigate genomic predictors and molecular mechanisms underlying the behavior. Once the bridge between genomic structure and metabolic function is built in one experimental system, the researchers will attempt to do the same in a more complex system that better approximates a natural context. The result will be a generalizable mapping from genomic structure to metabolic function that enables the rational design of microbial communities and provides a new quantitative interpretation of functional gene content.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
I have already given more granular insights into the nature of outcomes, results, etc. In particular, they focus on 3 manuscripts that were the primary scientific outcomes. I will not repeat those here. 
Instead, I believe during the life time of this grant I, in collaboration with the Kuehn Lab, and members of my own group, I was able to pursue the question "What is the role of quantitative modeling and theory in unraveling the mechanisms of microbial ecosystems?" And how does this interface with data?

 

Microbial ecosystems are enormously complex. There are dynamics at multiple time scales (I am ignoring the spatial aspects of the system for now) -- metabolism, gene expression, proliferation, growth, interactions between strains, chemical changes in soil activity and composition -- to name just a few. The often touted idea of multiscale modeling, though appealing to those who aren't mathematically experienced, is entirely absurd. Such a model would have such an over proliferation of parameters, and choices regarding the nonlinear nature of interactions, that it would be entirely sterile. Incapable for fitting data, making predictions, or providing mechanistic insights. 

Contrasting non-living systems, living systems, even ecosystems, have functionality. The issue of ecosystem function has a complex history. Microbial ecosystems, in my view, allow us to sidestep things. Half of the nitrogen cycle on the planet IS conducted by microbes, largely in soils. We thus, safely I believe, identify the kinetics of denitrification as the collective function that the microbial ecosystems that we are focusing on. The central idea of our work, broadly speaking, is to make mathematical dynamical models for this collective function. I emphasize that this function cannot be attributed to any single strain in the ecosystem -- it truly is a collective property of the entire system. Making such phenomenological models must be, as we did, guided by quantitative precision measurements made in the lab (or in nature) of the metabolic dynamics. The data provided qualitative constraints as to the nature of the mathematical model, which then in turn is leveraged to fit the data and perform parameteric estimations. Every ecosystem is now assigned parameters that enocde their collective metabolic dynamics. These parameters, I like to think, are the collective or emergent phenotypes. These phenotypes are now the properties that we can study. How do we they arise? What are their origins?

In the collection of studies we pursued, the modeling route to distilling phenotypes, allowed us to query their genetic origins (Gowda et a.) and their ecological origins (Lee et al.). In the absence of these quantitative phenotypes, distilling the genetic and/or ecological origins would be infeasible. 

This is a distinct approach to the central thrust in microbial ecology, or even biology as a whole. Disregard function, collect high dimensional data, use fancy ML/AI to analyze the data, and distil low dimensional structure in the data. Instead, we are taking the perspective that biological systems, though sometimes hard to distil, are functioning states of matter. Parametrizing functionality is essential, as a way to study, rationalize, and make sense of the high dimensional community compositions and gene expression data.
